Punk band Face to Face goes acoustic with its new ‘Hold Fast’ album and tour


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)

* Victorville punk rock band Face to Face (from left: Scott Shiflett, Trever Keith, Dennis Hill and Danny Thompson) will bring its Hold Fast Acoustic Tour to Hotel Cafe in Los Angeles on Friday, July 25; Observatory in Santa Ana on Thursday, July 26; And Romano’s Concert Lounge in Riverside on Sunday, July 29. (Photo courtesy of Face to Face)
By Kelli Skye Fadroski | kfadroski@scng.com | Orange County Register

PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 12:58 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 12:59 pm

Normally when Face to Face frontman Trever Keith hits the stage, it’s wild. Spit and sweat are flying everywhere, fans are passionately screaming along to Keith’s vocals, moshing hard in the pit and crowd surfing, hurling their flailing bodies over the barrier.


For this upcoming tour, however, things will be a bit different as the Victorville-based punk rock band has stripped down and rearranged some of its biggest hits and fan favorites that span the quartet’s 27-year career for its first acoustic album titled “Hold Fast,” which will be released Friday, July 27 via Fat Wreck Chords.


The album will be supported by a full tour, which includes three Southern California stops, starting at Hotel Cafe in Los Angeles on Wednesday, July 25, then the Observatory in Santa Ana on Thursday, July 26 and Romano’s Concert Lounge in Riverside on Sunday, July 29. All of the shows will feature opener Cory Branan, however the Orange County stop will also include acoustic sets by Jason Cruz of Strung Out and Scott Russo of Unwritten Law.


Following the success of the acoustic and unplugged albums and singles issued by bands such as Nirvana, Stone Temple Pilots, Soundgarden and Alice in Chains, a lot of artists were getting asked to follow suit. However when Keith was approached about it in the late ’90s and early ’00s, he wasn’t interested because it didn’t seem like the punk rock thing to do.


“I resisted for a very long time because we were a punk rock band and it just didn’t fit,” Keith said during a recent phone interview. “But, last year we did a tour and we offered one of our very first VIP packages and as part of that package I wanted to give something extra for the value and we decided to bring some acoustic guitars and do these little acoustic sets. Something just clicked. I don’t know if it was the relative age of us in the band and our fans and the place where we seem to be at in life, or if it’s the current climate of music or the culture, but it reacted very well with the audience and we were surprisingly really enjoying ourselves playing to them.”


After 27 years, these short acoustic sets gave the band a new artistic outlet and the path cleared very organically, Keith insists, as the VIP sessions led to the band wanting to record a few versions of the songs and commit to this alter ego of Face to Face, which would blossom into an album and a tour.


Related Articles

  * Same Same But Different music festival lands at Lake Perris in September
  * Friends Steve Martin and Martin Short are bringing their comedy and music show to 3 Southern California venues
  * 2 things to do at Southern California casinos this weekend (July 20-22)
  * Dirty Heads will launch its Vacation Pineapple Session Ale with a party at Huntington Beach’s Four Sons Brewing
  * How to get tickets for Rod Stewart and Pat Benatar with Neil Giraldo in Ontario

“This is something new that we are embracing,” he said. “As a band, we’ve done one-off things here and there acoustically, but we are committing to it on this tour and we’re starting things off here in our own backyard. As a Southern California band, we wanted to go to our family and our fans that have supported us since the ’90s and then there are more dates in September that bring us throughout the rest of the country as well. But we are committing to this and it’s not just like a novelty.”


The songs started out as a quick punk rock set with the guys pounding away on acoustic guitars, keeping the rhythms and maintaining the heaviness. Over the last year, Keith said they began to refine them and even took to social media to ask their loyal followers the top five songs they’d like to hear acoustic. At first, the band was going to stay far away from “Disconnected,” arguably its biggest hit, as well as the fast-paced “Ordinary.”


“People really wanted to hear ‘Disconnected’ and we were like, ‘OK, fine’,” Keith said with a laugh. “But actually, what we ended up recording and putting out on record came out really cool. I’m happy that we did take those requests to heart and challenged ourselves to make versions of those because ‘Ordinary’ was another one that I sat there like ‘How in the hell are we going to do that acoustic?’ It just didn’t make sense, but through a little re-thinking and re-imagining we were able to trump up a version and it ended up coming out great.”


A few of the other tracks, including “Don’t Turn Away” and “A-OK,” were given a bit of an Americana and country music vibe with the inclusion of a steel guitar. Keith said living in Nashville for a time did help him visualize how that style of music could fit, however, it was guitarist Dennis Hill and drummer Danny Thompson that had a lot to do with the introduction of that style.


“Dennis came up with at riff for ‘A-OK’ and I was resistant to it, like ‘Dude, we can’t go down this road,’ but then Danny came up with this beat and it was totally like Black Crowes when it started and I was like ‘I can’t do this,” Keith said. “It wasn’t a matter of if it was going too far or not, it was whether I feel comfortable and feel like I can be part of making that song and if it’s something authentic to the kind of music I’d like to make. I just wasn’t feeling it, but we kept hammering away at it until we had a version that everyone felt comfortable representing themselves as a player.”


Though a few of the songs dance in and out of the Americana and country genres, Keith said a lot of the influence on the record actually came from some of his favorite ’80s bands such as the Cure, the Smiths and the Psychedelic Furs.


“A lot of the simple songwriting comes from the love of those types of songs,” he said. “When I say that people might think I’m crazy because they picture the synthesizers and drum machines, but it’s not about the instrumentation, it’s about the way the songs are written and they’re simple pop songs. A lot of that has the same kind of sensibility too and the melancholy that comes with that. Maybe we’ve created a problem for ourselves in that there are a lot of different influences there so it may be hard for people to define ultimately. But it all lives in a place that is uniquely ours and hopefully that’s something people will be able to recognize and I’m hoping that’s a positive for us at the end of the day.”


To be clear, Keith said this is not the new “way” of Face to Face. The band will still get out there and melt faces at punk rock shows, however showcasing this style of performance could further open up its members to playing festivals and touring with acts they’d previously been passed up for.


If they hadn’t made this record, Keith said, they’d never have been asked to play with Lucero and Frank Turner at Red Rocks Amphitheatre in Colorado on Aug. 3.


“I mean, it’s also maybe a little bit of a retirement plan for us in a strange way,” he explained. “Not retiring from music, but playing punk rock is very physically demanding and if we want to be able to do this until we fall over and die it might be easier to do a few more of the acoustic shows and a few less of the punk rock shows as we age into the future. Hopefully that’s something that makes sense for us and for our fans, too.”


Face to Face’s Hold Fast Acoustic Tour


With: Cory Branan


When: 7 p.m. Wednesday, July 25


Where: 1623 N. Cahuenga Blvd., Hollywood


Tickets: 21-and-over only; $30 at HotelCafe.com


Next: 8 p.m. Thursday, July 26 with Cory Branan, Jason Cruz of Strung Out (acoustic) and Scott Russo from Unwritten Law (acoustic) at the Observatory, 3503 South Harbor Blvd., Santa Ana. All-ages; $20 at TicketWeb.com. And 8 p.m. Sunday, July 29 at Romano’s Concert Lounge, 3557 University Ave., Riverside. 21-and-over only; $25-$30 at TheConcertLounge.com.

Punk band Face to Face goes acoustic with its new ‘Hold Fast’ album and tour


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)

* Victorville punk rock band Face to Face (from left: Scott Shiflett, Trever Keith, Dennis Hill and Danny Thompson) will bring its Hold Fast Acoustic Tour to Hotel Cafe in Los Angeles on Friday, July 25; Observatory in Santa Ana on Thursday, July 26; And Romano’s Concert Lounge in Riverside on Sunday, July 29. (Photo courtesy of Face to Face)
By Kelli Skye Fadroski | kfadroski@scng.com | Orange County Register

PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 12:58 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 12:59 pm

Normally when Face to Face frontman Trever Keith hits the stage, it’s wild. Spit and sweat are flying everywhere, fans are passionately screaming along to Keith’s vocals, moshing hard in the pit and crowd surfing, hurling their flailing bodies over the barrier.


For this upcoming tour, however, things will be a bit different as the Victorville-based punk rock band has stripped down and rearranged some of its biggest hits and fan favorites that span the quartet’s 27-year career for its first acoustic album titled “Hold Fast,” which will be released Friday, July 27 via Fat Wreck Chords.


The album will be supported by a full tour, which includes three Southern California stops, starting at Hotel Cafe in Los Angeles on Wednesday, July 25, then the Observatory in Santa Ana on Thursday, July 26 and Romano’s Concert Lounge in Riverside on Sunday, July 29. All of the shows will feature opener Cory Branan, however the Orange County stop will also include acoustic sets by Jason Cruz of Strung Out and Scott Russo of Unwritten Law.


Following the success of the acoustic and unplugged albums and singles issued by bands such as Nirvana, Stone Temple Pilots, Soundgarden and Alice in Chains, a lot of artists were getting asked to follow suit. However when Keith was approached about it in the late ’90s and early ’00s, he wasn’t interested because it didn’t seem like the punk rock thing to do.


“I resisted for a very long time because we were a punk rock band and it just didn’t fit,” Keith said during a recent phone interview. “But, last year we did a tour and we offered one of our very first VIP packages and as part of that package I wanted to give something extra for the value and we decided to bring some acoustic guitars and do these little acoustic sets. Something just clicked. I don’t know if it was the relative age of us in the band and our fans and the place where we seem to be at in life, or if it’s the current climate of music or the culture, but it reacted very well with the audience and we were surprisingly really enjoying ourselves playing to them.”


After 27 years, these short acoustic sets gave the band a new artistic outlet and the path cleared very organically, Keith insists, as the VIP sessions led to the band wanting to record a few versions of the songs and commit to this alter ego of Face to Face, which would blossom into an album and a tour.


Related Articles

  * Same Same But Different music festival lands at Lake Perris in September
  * Friends Steve Martin and Martin Short are bringing their comedy and music show to 3 Southern California venues
  * 2 things to do at Southern California casinos this weekend (July 20-22)
  * Dirty Heads will launch its Vacation Pineapple Session Ale with a party at Huntington Beach’s Four Sons Brewing
  * How to get tickets for Rod Stewart and Pat Benatar with Neil Giraldo in Ontario

“This is something new that we are embracing,” he said. “As a band, we’ve done one-off things here and there acoustically, but we are committing to it on this tour and we’re starting things off here in our own backyard. As a Southern California band, we wanted to go to our family and our fans that have supported us since the ’90s and then there are more dates in September that bring us throughout the rest of the country as well. But we are committing to this and it’s not just like a novelty.”


The songs started out as a quick punk rock set with the guys pounding away on acoustic guitars, keeping the rhythms and maintaining the heaviness. Over the last year, Keith said they began to refine them and even took to social media to ask their loyal followers the top five songs they’d like to hear acoustic. At first, the band was going to stay far away from “Disconnected,” arguably its biggest hit, as well as the fast-paced “Ordinary.”


“People really wanted to hear ‘Disconnected’ and we were like, ‘OK, fine’,” Keith said with a laugh. “But actually, what we ended up recording and putting out on record came out really cool. I’m happy that we did take those requests to heart and challenged ourselves to make versions of those because ‘Ordinary’ was another one that I sat there like ‘How in the hell are we going to do that acoustic?’ It just didn’t make sense, but through a little re-thinking and re-imagining we were able to trump up a version and it ended up coming out great.”


A few of the other tracks, including “Don’t Turn Away” and “A-OK,” were given a bit of an Americana and country music vibe with the inclusion of a steel guitar. Keith said living in Nashville for a time did help him visualize how that style of music could fit, however, it was guitarist Dennis Hill and drummer Danny Thompson that had a lot to do with the introduction of that style.


“Dennis came up with at riff for ‘A-OK’ and I was resistant to it, like ‘Dude, we can’t go down this road,’ but then Danny came up with this beat and it was totally like Black Crowes when it started and I was like ‘I can’t do this,” Keith said. “It wasn’t a matter of if it was going too far or not, it was whether I feel comfortable and feel like I can be part of making that song and if it’s something authentic to the kind of music I’d like to make. I just wasn’t feeling it, but we kept hammering away at it until we had a version that everyone felt comfortable representing themselves as a player.”


Though a few of the songs dance in and out of the Americana and country genres, Keith said a lot of the influence on the record actually came from some of his favorite ’80s bands such as the Cure, the Smiths and the Psychedelic Furs.


“A lot of the simple songwriting comes from the love of those types of songs,” he said. “When I say that people might think I’m crazy because they picture the synthesizers and drum machines, but it’s not about the instrumentation, it’s about the way the songs are written and they’re simple pop songs. A lot of that has the same kind of sensibility too and the melancholy that comes with that. Maybe we’ve created a problem for ourselves in that there are a lot of different influences there so it may be hard for people to define ultimately. But it all lives in a place that is uniquely ours and hopefully that’s something people will be able to recognize and I’m hoping that’s a positive for us at the end of the day.”


To be clear, Keith said this is not the new “way” of Face to Face. The band will still get out there and melt faces at punk rock shows, however showcasing this style of performance could further open up its members to playing festivals and touring with acts they’d previously been passed up for.


If they hadn’t made this record, Keith said, they’d never have been asked to play with Lucero and Frank Turner at Red Rocks Amphitheatre in Colorado on Aug. 3.


“I mean, it’s also maybe a little bit of a retirement plan for us in a strange way,” he explained. “Not retiring from music, but playing punk rock is very physically demanding and if we want to be able to do this until we fall over and die it might be easier to do a few more of the acoustic shows and a few less of the punk rock shows as we age into the future. Hopefully that’s something that makes sense for us and for our fans, too.”


Face to Face’s Hold Fast Acoustic Tour


With: Cory Branan


When: 7 p.m. Wednesday, July 25


Where: 1623 N. Cahuenga Blvd., Hollywood


Tickets: 21-and-over only; $30 at HotelCafe.com


Next: 8 p.m. Thursday, July 26 with Cory Branan, Jason Cruz of Strung Out (acoustic) and Scott Russo from Unwritten Law (acoustic) at the Observatory, 3503 South Harbor Blvd., Santa Ana. All-ages; $20 at TicketWeb.com. And 8 p.m. Sunday, July 29 at Romano’s Concert Lounge, 3557 University Ave., Riverside. 21-and-over only; $25-$30 at TheConcertLounge.com.

* State Democrats endorse De León * Don't park in front of your own driveway * Pastrana’s big jump * Latest LeBron James Lakers News News Crime + Public Safety Storm cluster brings thunder, lightning, rain to Southern California, beaches evacuated Share this: * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window) * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window) * Click to print (Opens in new window) * By City News Service | PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 12:50 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 6:00 pm A lightning strike is seen Wednesday, July 18, 2018, in Van Nuys as a storm cell moves west over the Santa Monica Mountains south of the San Fernando Valley. Lighting strikes started some small spot fire in the hills, and local beaches were closed down due to lightning till the storm cells move out of the area. (Photo by Gene Blevins/Special to the Los Angeles Daily News)
Photo by Gene Blevins/LA DailyNews/SCNG LOS ANGELES — A cluster of thunderstorms rolled slowly across the Southland Wednesday, bringing bursts of rain that dampened streets and lightning strikes that prompted the closure of beaches in Santa Monica and Malibu, and may have started a couple small fires in Encino. Fueled by a flow of monsoonal moisture, the storms moved from east to west across the area, with rain and thunder reported in the San Gabriel Valley before the precipitation arrived in the West Los Angeles and West Hollywood area around 11:30 a.m. Rain was also reported in Burbank and other valley areas. Los Angeles Fire Department crews responded to a pair of small brush fires in the Encino area around the time the storm rolled in, prompting speculation that lightning strikes were to blame. Related Articles * LA rain and thunder strike in the middle of summer and Angelenos can’t deal * Highway 18, 38 reopen after closure due to flooding, mudslides in San Bernardino Mountains * Highway 18 near Big Bear reopens after ‘scary’ rockslides, intense rain * It’s not the heat, it’s the humidity – and the thunderstorms – in Southern California * Fontana mother arrested in Ontario after leaving babies in car in nearly 100-degree heat And a tree may have been hit on Sunset Boulevard near the beach. On Topanga Canyon Boulevard, a car flipped on its side in the heavy rain just up from the beach. No one was injured, the CHP said. Lightning was spotted in the Santa Monica area, prompting the city to issue an evacuation order for the ocean and beach areas. Authorities warned people to seek shelter indoors until the storm passed. The National Weather Service shared this image on Twitter of a cluster of thunderstorms about 11:30 a.m. Wednesday, July 18, 2018, over an area extending from West Hollywood to Santa Monica and moving west toward Topanga and Malibu. National Weather Service officials echoed that advice, with a Twitter post saying, “When thunder roars go indoors.” Los Angeles County lifeguards also closed beaches between Malibu and Zuma due to lightning. As of 12:40 p.m., all beaches in Malibu were closed, the city of Malibu reported. Thunderstorms are dangerous on the beach because sand “is a known conductor of electricity generated by lightning strikes in the ocean,” the city said on its web site. After the storm cells passed through the area, with no additional cells expected, LA County lifeguards reopened Malibu’s beaches about 1:30 p.m., the city reported on Twitter. Rainfall was concentrated in the Hollywood Hills and west into the Santa Monica Mountains. Totals included .17 inch at UCLA and .09 inches in Topanga Canyon. Forecasters said warm and humid conditions were expected to continue into Wednesday afternoon, with a slight chance of additional thunderstorms lingering into Wednesday evening. Daily News staff contributed to this report. By 12:20 p.m., showers and thunderstorms had moves west from Malibu and off the coast. Related Articles * LA rain and thunder strike in the middle of summer and Angelenos can’t deal * Highway 18, 38 reopen after closure due to flooding, mudslides in San Bernardino Mountains * Highway 18 near Big Bear reopens after ‘scary’ rockslides, intense rain * It’s not the heat, it’s the humidity – and the thunderstorms – in Southern California * Fontana mother arrested in Ontario after leaving babies in car in nearly 100-degree heat And a tree may have been hit on Sunset Boulevard near the beach. On Topanga Canyon Boulevard, a car flipped on its side in the heavy rain just up from the beach. No one was injured, the CHP said. Lightning was spotted in the Santa Monica area, prompting the city to issue an evacuation order for the ocean and beach areas. Authorities warned people to seek shelter indoors until the storm passed. The National Weather Service shared this image on Twitter of a cluster of thunderstorms about 11:30 a.m. Wednesday, July 18, 2018, over an area extending from West Hollywood to Santa Monica and moving west toward Topanga and Malibu. National Weather Service officials echoed that advice, with a Twitter post saying, “When thunder roars go indoors.” Los Angeles County lifeguards also closed beaches between Malibu and Zuma due to lightning. As of 12:40 p.m., all beaches in Malibu were closed, the city of Malibu reported. Thunderstorms are dangerous on the beach because sand “is a known conductor of electricity generated by lightning strikes in the ocean,” the city said on its web site. After the storm cells passed through the area, with no additional cells expected, LA County lifeguards reopened Malibu’s beaches about 1:30 p.m., the city reported on Twitter. Rainfall was concentrated in the Hollywood Hills and west into the Santa Monica Mountains. Totals included .17 inch at UCLA and .09 inches in Topanga Canyon. Forecasters said warm and humid conditions were expected to continue into Wednesday afternoon, with a slight chance of additional thunderstorms lingering into Wednesday evening. Daily News staff contributed to this report. By 12:20 p.m., showers and thunderstorms had moves west from Malibu and off the coast. 3-hour SUV chase on 5 Freeway takes CHP through LA, Orange Counties

* By City News Service |
PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 6:02 am | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 12:24 pm

SANTA CLARITA — A woman was in custody Wednesday, accused of leading California Highway Patrol officers on a chase along the northbound 5 Freeway from the San Diego area to Santa Clarita.


The chase began about 7:30 p.m. Tuesday on westbound state Route 52, approaching state Route 125 in Santee when officers tried to pull over the driver of a Nissan Rogue SUV for speeding, according to Officer M. Bailey of the California Highway Patrol’s San Diego Office.


The pursuit traveled north for nearly three hours until the vehicle drove over spike strips deployed by officers near the McBean Parkway exit, NBC4 reported.


The driver stopped the SUV in the middle lane of the freeway near Magic Mountain Parkway, and officers moved in, pulled her from the vehicle and took her into custody.


The rear of the SUV was damaged from non-lethal rounds fired by officers in an attempt to get the driver to surrender, NBC4 said.


Throughout the chase, the driver used her turn signals when changing lanes.


KCAL9 reported the driver may not have been the registered owner of the SUV.

Canada resident reported missing in Joshua Tree National Park


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)

* Searchers look for missing Canada resident Paul Miller in Joshua Tree National Park on July 16, 2018. (Courtesy of National Park Service)
By Brian Rokos | brokos@scng.com | The Press-Enterprise

PUBLISHED: July 17, 2018 at 9:54 pm | UPDATED: July 17, 2018 at 9:54 pm

Searchers on Tuesday, July 17, continued to look for a 51-year-old Canada resident who disappeared while hiking at Joshua Tree National Park.


Paul Miller was last seen by his wife about 9 a.m. Friday when he left for a hike on the 49 Palms Oasis trail. She reported him overdue about noon. His car was found in the parking lot at the trailhead.


Missing hiker in the 49 Palms Oasis area. If you have any information please call 909-383-5651. pic.twitter.com/CcHMcJiKfw


— Joshua Tree NPS (@JoshuaTreeNPS) July 14, 2018


Joshua Tree National Park Search and Rescue and the San Bernardino County Sheriff’s Department are participating in the search, according to the park’s Facebook page.


A friend, Ainsley Otten, said on the Facebook page that Miller is “a fairly experienced outdoorsman and was likely more prepared than most.”


The trail and parking lot are closed to the public during the search.


Officials ask that anyone with information on Miller’s whereabouts or who has any other helpful details call 909-383-5651.

Crime + Public Safety


Canada resident reported missing in Joshua Tree National Park


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)

* Searchers look for missing Canada resident Paul Miller in Joshua Tree National Park on July 16, 2018. (Courtesy of National Park Service)
By Brian Rokos | brokos@scng.com | The Press-Enterprise

PUBLISHED: July 17, 2018 at 9:54 pm | UPDATED: July 17, 2018 at 9:54 pm

Searchers on Tuesday, July 17, continued to look for a 51-year-old Canada resident who disappeared while hiking at Joshua Tree National Park.


Paul Miller was last seen by his wife about 9 a.m. Friday when he left for a hike on the 49 Palms Oasis trail. She reported him overdue about noon. His car was found in the parking lot at the trailhead.


Missing hiker in the 49 Palms Oasis area. If you have any information please call 909-383-5651. pic.twitter.com/CcHMcJiKfw


— Joshua Tree NPS (@JoshuaTreeNPS) July 14, 2018


Joshua Tree National Park Search and Rescue and the San Bernardino County Sheriff’s Department are participating in the search, according to the park’s Facebook page.


A friend, Ainsley Otten, said on the Facebook page that Miller is “a fairly experienced outdoorsman and was likely more prepared than most.”


The trail and parking lot are closed to the public during the search.


Officials ask that anyone with information on Miller’s whereabouts or who has any other helpful details call 909-383-5651.

* State Democrats endorse De León * Don't park in front of your own driveway * Pastrana’s big jump * Latest LeBron James Lakers News News Crime + Public Safety Canyon Lake man convicted of second-degree murder in shooting death of his best friend Share this: * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window) * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window) * Click to print (Opens in new window) * By City News Service | PUBLISHED: July 17, 2018 at 9:26 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 2:13 am RIVERSIDE — A 22-year-old Canyon Lake man who blasted his best friend with a shotgun in Moreno Valley in what the prosecution argued was a case of intimate feelings gone sour was convicted Tuesday of second-degree murder. After three days of deliberations, a Riverside jury found Houston Michael Boji guilty of the Nov. 10, 2015, shooting death of 18-year-old Nicholas McCauley of Moreno Valley. Houston Michael Boji
File photo The jury also found true sentence-enhancing gun and great bodily injury allegations, and Boji is expected to be sentenced on Sept. 7 to 40 years to life in state prison. Deputy District Attorney Sharunne Foster argued that Boji intended to kill McCauley and telegraphed his intentions well in advance with threatening texts, including one stating, “I’m serious. I will shoot you when I see you mother(expletive).” She theorized that Boji had developed passionate feelings for his longtime friend, with whom he socialized almost daily, and became incensed when McCauley did not reciprocate. The defendant and victim had spent time with each other four days before the Nov. 10, 2015, shooting, and Boji ended up with a cold sore afterward, which the prosecution suggested was the result of intimate contact. When Boji texted complaints to McCauley regarding his physical discomfort and unhappiness, the victim evidently did not respond, igniting anger in the defendant, who vowed to shoot McCauley the next time they met, according to the prosecution. Sheriff’s investigators said Boji armed himself with a fully loaded 12-gauge pump shotgun and went to his friend’s residence in the 25000 block of Soaring Seagull Lane, waited until the victim’s mother left for work, then slipped into the house, where McCauley was still asleep in his bedroom. Boji fired one round into McCauley’s left arm at close range — so close that the buckshot dispersed throughout the sleeping victim’s entire chest cavity, killing him on the spot, according to the prosecution. Sign up for our breaking news email newsletter: When major local news happens, you will be the first to know. Subscribe here. The defendant initially told detectives that McCauley had killed himself, but in succeeding statements admitted firing the shot. According to Boji’s attorneys, he never wanted to kill the victim. The defense argued that there were no homosexual impulses, and that Boji was only interested in scaring McCauley because of a minor dispute, without realizing the shotgun was loaded. Boji has no documented prior felony convictions. Get the latest news delivered daily! * Traffic was affected on the westbound 60 Freeway in Ontario on July 6 because of a collision. (Courtesy of Caltrans)
By Brian Rokos | brokos@scng.com | The Press-Enterprise

PUBLISHED: July 6, 2018 at 12:58 pm | UPDATED: July 6, 2018 at 2:35 pm

This story corrects a previous version that incorrectly stated that a CHP unit crashed.


The two right lanes of the westbound 60 Freeway in Ontario were closed early Friday afternoon, July 6, after an Ontario police unit collided with a tow truck, the California Highway Patrol said.


A tractor-trailer also was involved in the collision, which was reported just before noon, according to the CHP incident log. All lanes were initially closed.

Sign up for our breaking news email newsletter: When major local news happens, you will be the first to know. Subscribe here.

Both officers were out of the patrol car.


“Both officers are okay because they were wearing their seatbelts,” Police Chief Derek Williams said.


There was no immediate word on injuries to others.


The CHP is investigating the collision.

Brush fires in Cajon Pass prompt brief SigAlert on 15 Freeway


Share this:

* By Beatriz E. Valenzuela | bvalenzuela@scng.com | San Bernardino Sun
PUBLISHED: June 27, 2018 at 12:37 pm | UPDATED: June 27, 2018 at 2:30 pm

Two small brush fires along the northbound 15 Freeway in the Cajon Pass Wednesday afternoon prompted California Highway Patrol officials to shut down lanes of traffic and issued a SigAlert, according to initial CHP reports.


The fires were first reported around 11:30 a.m. near Kenwood Drive.


U.S. Forest Service fire crews and air support responded to this fire. The rate of spread has stopped. Total of four acres between two small fires near Kenwood and the I-15. https://t.co/ySj2nvfNcC


— San Bernardino National Forest (@SanBernardinoNF) June 27, 2018


The two wildfires scorched a combined 4 acres before firefighters managed to stop it’s forward spread, according to National Forest Service authorities.


8 mins ago via sister pic.twitter.com/ssoIGGccA8


— Kerry Lovelock (@klovelock3) June 27, 2018


A SigAlert was briefly issued and at least one lane of traffic on the northbound 15 Freeway was shut down to allow firefighters to extinguish the flames, officials said.

Beatriz E. Valenzuela is an award-winning journalist who’s covered breaking news in Southern California since 2006 and has been on the front lines of several national and international news events. Brush fires in Cajon Pass prompt brief SigAlert on 15 Freeway


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)
* By Beatriz E. Valenzuela | bvalenzuela@scng.com | San Bernardino Sun
PUBLISHED: June 27, 2018 at 12:37 pm | UPDATED: June 27, 2018 at 2:30 pm

Two small brush fires along the northbound 15 Freeway in the Cajon Pass Wednesday afternoon prompted California Highway Patrol officials to shut down lanes of traffic and issued a SigAlert, according to initial CHP reports.


The fires were first reported around 11:30 a.m. near Kenwood Drive.


U.S. Forest Service fire crews and air support responded to this fire. The rate of spread has stopped. Total of four acres between two small fires near Kenwood and the I-15. https://t.co/ySj2nvfNcC


— San Bernardino National Forest (@SanBernardinoNF) June 27, 2018


The two wildfires scorched a combined 4 acres before firefighters managed to stop it’s forward spread, according to National Forest Service authorities.


8 mins ago via sister pic.twitter.com/ssoIGGccA8


— Kerry Lovelock (@klovelock3) June 27, 2018


A SigAlert was briefly issued and at least one lane of traffic on the northbound 15 Freeway was shut down to allow firefighters to extinguish the flames, officials said.

California’s gas tax repeal is now officially headed to a ballot near you


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)

* Katie Martinez of Oakland talks to this newspaper on Dec. 19, 2017 in Oakland about her views on the proposed initiative to repeal the state’s recently enacted gas tax to fund road and highway repair, and a proposed bridge toll hike of up to $3 for most bridges spanning the Bay Area. (Dai Sugano/Bay Area News Group)
By Erin Baldassari | ebaldassari@bayareanewsgroup.com | Bay Area News Group

PUBLISHED: June 25, 2018 at 2:27 pm | UPDATED: June 25, 2018 at 6:05 pm

Setting the stage for a major statewide battle over how to pay for an estimated $67 billion backlog in highway, bridge and road repairs, a ballot measure to repeal California’s recently enacted gas taxes and registration fees officially qualified Monday for the November ballot.


Already, Gov. Jerry Brown and a powerful coalition of chambers of commerce, law enforcement, unions, firefighters, local transportation agencies and cities and counties have vowed to fight it.


“I will do everything in my power to defeat any repeal effort,” Brown said in a statement shortly after the Secretary of State’s Office announced the effort had qualified for the ballot. “You can count on that.”


John Cox, the Republican candidate for governor, didn’t waste any time, either, to voice his support for the repeal.


“This is a message to the millions of forgotten Californians ignored by the Sacramento political elite, help is on the way,” Cox said. “Let this also be a message to every special interest in Sacramento, we’re coming for you.”


The taxes and fees have strong support in the Bay Area, according to a recent USC and Los Angeles Times poll, where a booming economy has driven up the price of housing, forcing workers to commute longer distances through maddening traffic and where 72 percent of likely voters said they would keep the tax.


But that enthusiasm would not be enough to retain the tax, the poll found, because support is weak nearly everywhere else. Only 38 percent of Los Angeles-area voters, 29 percent of voters elsewhere in Southern California, and 30 percent of Central Valley voters support it.


Without the new taxes and fees, California residents will be stuck right back where they started, with not enough money to fund needed highway maintenance, road repairs or public transit upgrades, said repeal opponent Carl Guardino, the CEO of the business-focused Silicon Valley Leadership Group and a member of the California Transportation Commission.


“Those stating we can fund those improvements without the funds generated from California’s first gas tax increase in 25 years are either mistaken or are flat-out misleading California voters,” he said via email. “If this misleading repeal is successful in November, more than half of those improvements grind to a halt, along with our region’s economy and quality of life.”


Already, more than 5,000 state and local transportation projects are underway using money generated from the new taxes and fees, according to the California Transportation Commission. State transportation officials estimate roughly half of those projects would be delayed or indefinitely deferred if the repeal succeeds, including $3.1 billion for transit and highway projects in the Bay Area alone.


Approved by the legislature and signed into law last year, Senate Bill 1, which went into effect in November, raised the tax on gasoline by 12 cents per gallon and increased the tax on diesel by 20 cents per gallon. It also raised registration fees this year by $25 to $175, depending on the value of the vehicle, and imposed a $100 registration fee for zero-emission vehicles, which will go into effect in 2020.


The taxes and fees are expected to generate roughly $54 billion over the next 10 years to chip away at the state’s deferred maintenance backlog and help pay for upgrades to public transit. The increases nearly double the amount cities and counties receive annually to repair local streets and roads.


Opponents of the tax say the state has poorly managed the transportation money it already has. Too often over the past 20 years, they say, politicians raided transportation funding to balance the state’s budget, limiting the state’s ability to pay for highway and road maintenance, which only made the eventual repairs more expensive.


It’s hard to get a good accounting of how much money was diverted and how much has been repaid, said David Wolfe, the legislative director at the Howard Jarvis Taxpayers Association, which opposes the taxes and fees. A 2016 UCLA report cited at least three times in the mid-1990s and 2000s when the state used money to balance the budget that was supposed to repair highways and roads or upgrade public transit.


Changes to the state constitution now prohibit such transfers in most cases.


Wolfe highlighted another redirection of transportation funding: Voters approved several general obligation bonds over the years to pay for large transportation projects with the expectation that the principal would be paid from the general fund. But a complicated funding measure called the “Gas Tax Swap” enabled legislators to use truck weight fees, which previously paid for highway and road maintenance, to pay off transportation-related debt, instead. That amounts to about $7 billion since the swap went into effect.


“The roads will not get fixed because the politicians will continue to divert the funds as they always have in the past,” Carl DeMaio, who is leading the repeal effort, said in a statement Monday. The Legislative Analyst’s Office estimates that, with the new taxes, the average driver will pay $750 per year in taxes and fees.


But proponents note that the last time the gas tax was raised was in 1994, when it increased from 9 cents to 18 cents, and argue that it’s due for an increase. It’s not hard to see how the backlog of deferred maintenance grew, said Martin Wachs, an urban planning professor emeritus at UCLA, when you consider seismic retrofit projects that lengthened the list of needed repairs statewide, and several recessions that reduced the money the state anticipated collecting.


Even if money dedicated to transportation was diverted to the general fund, for the most part, it’s been repaid, he said.


“It’s also true that the occasions when that has been done have been really rare and have occurred in times of fiscal emergency,” Wachs said. “The main problem is the lack of buying power of the gas tax, unless it is raised, to keep up with inflation.”

CHP: At least 20 cars involved in fog-related crashes on 15 Freeway in Cajon Pass


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)

* Authorities report a two-mile-long multi-vehicle accident in dense fog in the Cajon Pass (Courtesy San Bernardino County Fire Department)
By Richard K. De Atley | rdeatley@scng.com | The Press-Enterprise

PUBLISHED: May 30, 2018 at 12:27 pm | UPDATED: May 30, 2018 at 6:09 pm

A chain-collision of vehicles in dense fog Wednesday turned a stretch of the southbound 15 Freeway in the Cajon Pass into a mile-long trail of crumpled cars, injured multiple people, and stuck motorists in a backup that stretched 10 miles at one point, authorities said.


The fog will be back in the pass Thursday, the National Weather Service said. Electronic billboards in the area will warn motorists to slow down, but they should “avoid travel if they can,” said Caltrans spokeswoman Terri Kasinga. “It’s not safe driving in the fog.”


San Bernardino County Fire Department reported 17 injuries from the scene, and the California Highway Patrol incident log said eight people were sent to hospitals. Firefighters also said there were “numerous drivers and occupants declining treatment.” None of the injuries was life-threatening, the CHP said.


The crashes started at 10:42 a.m. when two vehicles heading southbound on the freeway were disabled in a collision south of Oak Hill Road, blocking lanes of traffic and starting a chain reaction of crashes, the CHP said in a release. A SigAlert was called.


  * A multi-vehicle traffic collision on the southbound 15 freeway in the Cajon Pass shut down the freeway and backed up traffic into Oak Hills. (Stan Lim/The Sun-SCNG)


  * California Highway Patrol and San Bernardino County Fire Department officials responded to reports of multiple collisions on the 15 Freeway Wednesday afternoon in the Cajon Pass. (Photo courtesy of the San Bernardino County Fire Department)

  * Sound
    The gallery will resume inseconds

  * California Highway Patrol and San Bernardino County Fire Department officials responded to reports of multiple collisions on the 15 Freeway Wednesday afternoon in the Cajon Pass. (Photo courtesy of the San Bernardino County Fire Department)


  * The California Highway Patrol said visibility was at 30 feet at the scene of a multi-vehicle pileup Wednesday in the Cajon Pass . (Courtesty San Bernardino County Fire Department)


  * California Highway Patrol and San Bernardino County Fire Department officials responded to reports of multiple collisions on the 15 Freeway Wednesday afternoon in the Cajon Pass. (Photo courtesy of the San Bernardino County Fire Department)


  * Authorities report a mile-long multi-vehicle accident in dense fog in the Cajon Pass (Courtesy San Bernardino County Fire Department)

Show Caption
of

Expand


The southbound lanes were eventually all closed with all gradually reopening by 1:20 p.m. The affected area was roughly from south of Oak Hill Road to north of the brake check area — there are few landmarks where the crashes occurred — CHP Officer Marcelo Llerena said.


“There were multiple separate collisions, it’s about a mile long,” Llerena said by phone. “There were a lot of two-or-three-or-four car (collisions),” he said.


Fire officials said traffic was backed up to Main Street in Hesperia due to the collisons, which Llerena said was a 10-mile lineup.


Between 20 to 30 cars were estimated to be involved, but the CHP said Wednesday afternoon it was still counting how many cars and people were involved in the various wrecks.


Amid the confusion, a CHP officer helped two stranded graduating seniors from Mojave High School in Hesperia by giving them a lift to their graduation at the Glen Helen Amphitheater near Devore, CHP Officer Brian Alvarez said.

Sign up for our breaking news email newsletter: When major local news happens, you will be the first to know. Subscribe here.

At the time of the crashes, the CHP said visibility in the area was about 30 feet.


“Unfortunately, we are going to do it all over again,” NWS-San Diego meteorologist Dan Gregoria said Wednesday. He said the marine layer from the coast will be strong enough to again push into the Cajon Pass, rolling in overnight and staying until late Thursday morning.


“It could be severe, with restrictions in visibility,” Gregoria said. “Slow down and leave a good distance between you and other drivers.” Gregoria said the pattern will change for the weekend, with the marine layer more shallow and less likely to reach the Inland area.


The CHP asked anyone with information about the incident to call their San Bernardino office at (909) 383-4247.


Northbound traffic didn’t stop, but was slow because of the fog and the distraction of the pileups in the southbound lanes, Llerena said. The CHP had 16 to 17 units at the scene to help clear the lanes and control traffic, among other work.


Staff Writer Beatriz E. Valenzuela contributed to this report.

Local News


LA rain and thunder strike in the middle of summer and Angelenos can’t deal


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)

* Rain hit parts of Los Angeles Wednesday afternoon.
By Angela Ratzlaff |

PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 1:38 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 2:20 pm

You could say Los Angeles is a stranger to rain, especially during the summertime.


So when some droplets and a few strikes of lightning hit around the Hollywood area early Wednesday afternoon – in the middle of July – locals couldn’t believe what they were seeing.


There is, however, an explanation for this rare occurrence. It’s monsoon season and the result is muggy moisture in Southern California.


Increasing monsoonal moisture will bring a threat of thunderstorms to portions of SW Calif Wed into Thu. Greatest threats will be brief heavy downpours with isolated flash flooding as well as strong wind gusts. #LAWeather #LArain #cawx #Socal pic.twitter.com/awWdL55tgZ


— NWS Los Angeles (@NWSLosAngeles) July 17, 2018


Parts of Los Angeles started seeing rain at around 11 a.m.


#LARain: Heavy downpour and thunder in the #HollywoodHills round 11:30a @NBCLA pic.twitter.com/LDYNFXG08l


— Robert Kovacik (@RobertNBCLA) July 18, 2018


Light showers developing in the San Gabriel Valley with .02" reported in Pasadena in the last hour. Showers moving southwest towards Hollywood and Beverly Hills. pic.twitter.com/bZGFZWzMwb


— NWS Los Angeles (@NWSLosAngeles) July 18, 2018


At 1130am…a cluster of thunderstorms from West Hollywood to Santa Monica is moving west toward Topanga and Malibu. When Thunder Roars Go Indoors! #LARain #LAWeather #CAwx pic.twitter.com/QrbsOQhpMM


— NWS Los Angeles (@NWSLosAngeles) July 18, 2018


At 1220pm, showers and thunderstorms have moved west from Malibu and off the coast south of Anacapa and Santa Cruz Islands. Please wait 30 minutes after last thunder before leaving your home or car. Storms are moving quickly WSW at 30 mph. #LARain #LAWeather #CAwx pic.twitter.com/P9MxiaOjIs


— NWS Los Angeles (@NWSLosAngeles) July 18, 2018


Around 1 p.m., Malibu even issued a warning and closed its beaches due to safety concerns.


All #Malibu beaches are closed due to lightning. LA County Lifeguards closed and cleared beaches at 12:40 PM due to public safety concerns about lightning moving from Santa Monica through Malibu. Lifeguards are expected to re-open beaches later today. https://t.co/fLzBfZLw6u pic.twitter.com/SzI4QMqHNy


— MalibuPublicSafety (@MalibuEOC) July 18, 2018


The unexpected weather had some people scratching their heads.


Raise your hand if you just Googled "weather los angeles." #LArain


— Whitney Friedlander (@loislane79) July 18, 2018


Literally everyone in the office right now: What’s that sound? Are construction workers watering the roof?


OH IT’S RAIN#LARain


— Elizabeth Jones (@SocalledLizzie) July 18, 2018


It’s currently raining & the weather app just doesn’t understand how to say there is a rain in LA #LArain pic.twitter.com/xDJipQEFh3


— Tanner Baillargeon (@managertanner) July 18, 2018


A THUNDERSTORM in LA in the middle of July?!?! The world is definitely ending #LArain ⛈️


— Laura Jerpi Woods (@MrsLauraWoods) July 18, 2018


Are those missiles hitting Los Angeles? Because I know it can’t be a thunderstorm.


— Amy Berg (@bergopolis) July 18, 2018


I've lived in Los Angeles for like 2.5 years now and this is my first time ever hearing thunder here WHAT IS HAPPENING #LArain pic.twitter.com/Q62IAiuNaX


— Ashley . (@2ysub2ysur) July 18, 2018


But since the rain affected small pockets of Los Angeles, a lot of people got jealous that they didn’t see any water fall from the sky.


When you see #LArain trending but you don't actually see any rain in your part of L.A. pic.twitter.com/MLYHBEqldQ


— 🤷🏽‍♀️ kiki 🤦🏽‍♀️ (@heyjdey) July 18, 2018


All of these people tweeting about #LArain and #Thunder, and I'm over here in the Playa area by LAX like… pic.twitter.com/pvrA3xVNK7


— Lindsey (@asimpledroid) July 18, 2018


And for others from out of state, it was more of a laughing matter.


This Midwest girl seeing #LArain trend pic.twitter.com/WhCFfRK0tI


— Meaghan Downs (@writemegwrite) July 18, 2018


When someone from Seattle sees #LArain trending pic.twitter.com/eTU3FK3Gux


— TimmyTech📺 (@TimmyTechTV) July 18, 2018

LA rain and thunder strike in the middle of summer and Angelenos can’t deal


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)

* Rain hit parts of Los Angeles Wednesday afternoon.
By Angela Ratzlaff |

PUBLISHED: July 18, 2018 at 1:38 pm | UPDATED: July 18, 2018 at 2:20 pm

You could say Los Angeles is a stranger to rain, especially during the summertime.


So when some droplets and a few strikes of lightning hit around the Hollywood area early Wednesday afternoon – in the middle of July – locals couldn’t believe what they were seeing.


There is, however, an explanation for this rare occurrence. It’s monsoon season and the result is muggy moisture in Southern California.


Increasing monsoonal moisture will bring a threat of thunderstorms to portions of SW Calif Wed into Thu. Greatest threats will be brief heavy downpours with isolated flash flooding as well as strong wind gusts. #LAWeather #LArain #cawx #Socal pic.twitter.com/awWdL55tgZ


— NWS Los Angeles (@NWSLosAngeles) July 17, 2018


Parts of Los Angeles started seeing rain at around 11 a.m.


#LARain: Heavy downpour and thunder in the #HollywoodHills round 11:30a @NBCLA pic.twitter.com/LDYNFXG08l


— Robert Kovacik (@RobertNBCLA) July 18, 2018


Light showers developing in the San Gabriel Valley with .02" reported in Pasadena in the last hour. Showers moving southwest towards Hollywood and Beverly Hills. pic.twitter.com/bZGFZWzMwb


— NWS Los Angeles (@NWSLosAngeles) July 18, 2018


At 1130am…a cluster of thunderstorms from West Hollywood to Santa Monica is moving west toward Topanga and Malibu. When Thunder Roars Go Indoors! #LARain #LAWeather #CAwx pic.twitter.com/QrbsOQhpMM

— NWS Los Angeles (@NWSLosAngeles) July 18, 2018


Around 1 p.m., Malibu even issued a warning and closed its beaches due to safety concerns.


All #Malibu beaches are closed due to lightning. LA County Lifeguards closed and cleared beaches at 12:40 PM due to public safety concerns about lightning moving from Santa Monica through Malibu. Lifeguards are expected to re-open beaches later today. https://t.co/fLzBfZLw6u pic.twitter.com/SzI4QMqHNy


— MalibuPublicSafety (@MalibuEOC) July 18, 2018

Highway 18 near Big Bear reopens after ‘scary’ rockslides, intense rain


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)

* A National Weather Service radar analysis shows how much rain fell in the San Bernardino Mountains through 3 p.m. Wednesday, July 11, 2018. The highest total was 2.8 inches just west of Big Bear Lake and north of Highway 18. (Image via National Weather Service)
By Nikie Johnson | nijohnson@scng.com |

PUBLISHED: July 11, 2018 at 1:23 pm | UPDATED: July 11, 2018 at 8:34 pm

A 7-mile stretch of Highway 18 near Big Bear in the San Bernardino Mountains was shut down for a couple of hours Wednesday, July 11, because of rockfalls and mudslides caused by heavy rain.


One woman who drove through it with her two nephews — but managed to avoid damage — called it an awful, scary situation with rocks bigger than a basketball falling in front of her SUV and many vehicles getting stuck.


The highway reopened about 1:40 p.m. once the mess was cleaned up, though drivers were warned to continue to be careful because the thunderstorms haven’t ended.


Highway 18 between Snow Summit and Big Bear dam has reopened. Drive careful, as there are still thunderstorms in the mountains. @Caltrans8


— San Bernardino National Forest (@SanBernardinoNF) July 11, 2018


A flash-flood watch is in effect in the mountains and high deserts of San Bernardino and Riverside counties through 7 p.m., while flood warnings and advisories have been issued for specific locations within those areas as immediate hazards have popped up.


Flash Flood Warning including Victorville CA, Apple Valley CA, Lucerne Valley CA until 6:00 PM PDT pic.twitter.com/3BFi2zs9JT


— NWS San Diego (@NWSSanDiego) July 11, 2018


A radar analysis indicates that by 3 p.m., the storm had dumped up to 2.8 inches of rain in the San Bernardino Mountains, with the heaviest rainfall just west of Big Bear Lake and north of Highway 18.


Both lanes of the 18 became blocked by rocks about 11:30 a.m., and the highway was shut down between the dam at the western end of the lake and Snow Valley.


Jessica Guyette, 30, was driving her nephews, 7-year-old Noah and 8-year-old Nick, in the Arctic Circle area between Big Bear and Running Springs when they got caught in the rockslide.


“Rocks were falling in front of my car, mud was coming down,” she said. Most ranged from the size of a baseball to the size of a basketball, and the largest rocks were the size of two or three basketballs together.


“It was scary,” she said.


In her Toyota 4Runner, Guyette — a lifelong Big Bear resident who said as bad as it was, she’s seen worse — was able to navigate around the rocks and mud, but lower-clearance vehicles around her weren’t so lucky. She said she saw lots of people stopped, and wasn’t sure if they had been damaged or got flat tires from the rocks or just didn’t want to try to get through the mud.

Sign up for our breaking news email newsletter: When major local news happens, you will be the first to know. Subscribe here.

She told her nephews they were lucky to have made it through safely before the road closed.


Guyette posted a video to Twitter of Noah giving a warning to others: “You guys,” he says from inside the car as the rain outside can be heard, “we are up in Big Bear so you might want to be prepared with a umbrella and a — a heavy-duty jacket, because it is very, very rainy.”


Nick chimes in, “And stay in your house.”


Noah continues, “There’s a whole bunch of rocks falling down off the mountain, and a whole bunch of mud.”


Glad I made it out of that mess! #ArcticCircle #bigbear pic.twitter.com/twOFwY21su


— Jessica Guyette (@JessGRealtor) July 11, 2018


Tow trucks were called to help the vehicles that weren’t as lucky as Guyette and got stuck in the closure, according to a CHP incident log.


About 10 miles south, rain was also falling, but less intensely, in the Forest Falls area where the 1,348-acre Valley fire is still burning. That area saw thunderstorms and mudslides on Saturday. On Wednesday afternoon, only a few tenths of an inch of rain had fallen in Forest Falls, according to the weather service, but heavier rain was falling to the north and south.

It’s not the heat, it’s the humidity – and the thunderstorms – in Southern California


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)
* By City News Service |
PUBLISHED: July 10, 2018 at 10:34 am | UPDATED: July 10, 2018 at 10:34 am

Click for a larger image.

LOS ANGELES — New wrinkles will appear in the Southland’s sweltering weather Tuesday in the form of muggy conditions and precipitation.


The National Weather Service said there’s a 20 percent chance of showers or thunderstorms Tuesday afternoon in the San Gabriel and Antelope valleys, and a slight chance of the same in the San Gabriel Mountains some time Tuesday.


The NWS forecast mostly cloudy skies in L.A. County Tuesday and highs of 80 in San Pedro; 83 degrees in Avalon; 85 at LAX and in Torrance; 86 in Long Beach and on Mount Wilson; 91 in Burbank and Whittier; 92 in downtown Los Angeles and North Hollywood; 93 in San Gabriel; 95 in Pasadena, Van Nuys and West Covina; 96 in Northridge and Santa Clarita; 97 in Woodland Hills; 98 in Lancaster; and 99 in Palmdale.


Partly cloudy skies were forecast in Orange Country, along with highs of 82 in San Clemente; 85 in Newport Beach and Laguna Beach; 91 in Anaheim; 92 in Fullerton, Irvine and Santa Ana; 93 in Mission Viejo; and 95 in Yorba Linda.


In San Bernardino County on Tuesday, forecasted highs are 72 in Big Bear; 75 in Running Springs; 79 in Wrightwood; 89 in Yucaipa; 95 in Rancho Cucamonga, Redlands and Victorville; 91 in Hesperia; and 96 in Ontario and San Bernardino.


Tuesday’s temperatures will be about the same as Monday’s. Temperatures will be slightly lower Wednesday.

PUBLISHED: July 10, 2018 at 10:34 am | UPDATED: July 10, 2018 at 10:34 am

Click for a larger image.

LOS ANGELES — New wrinkles will appear in the Southland’s sweltering weather Tuesday in the form of muggy conditions and precipitation.


The National Weather Service said there’s a 20 percent chance of showers or thunderstorms Tuesday afternoon in the San Gabriel and Antelope valleys, and a slight chance of the same in the San Gabriel Mountains some time Tuesday.


The NWS forecast mostly cloudy skies in L.A. County Tuesday and highs of 80 in San Pedro; 83 degrees in Avalon; 85 at LAX and in Torrance; 86 in Long Beach and on Mount Wilson; 91 in Burbank and Whittier; 92 in downtown Los Angeles and North Hollywood; 93 in San Gabriel; 95 in Pasadena, Van Nuys and West Covina; 96 in Northridge and Santa Clarita; 97 in Woodland Hills; 98 in Lancaster; and 99 in Palmdale.


Partly cloudy skies were forecast in Orange Country, along with highs of 82 in San Clemente; 85 in Newport Beach and Laguna Beach; 91 in Anaheim; 92 in Fullerton, Irvine and Santa Ana; 93 in Mission Viejo; and 95 in Yorba Linda.


In San Bernardino County on Tuesday, forecasted highs are 72 in Big Bear; 75 in Running Springs; 79 in Wrightwood; 89 in Yucaipa; 95 in Rancho Cucamonga, Redlands and Victorville; 91 in Hesperia; and 96 in Ontario and San Bernardino.


Tuesday’s temperatures will be about the same as Monday’s. Temperatures will be slightly lower Wednesday.

Crime + Public Safety


Fontana mother arrested in Ontario after leaving babies in car in nearly 100-degree heat


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)
* By Beatriz E. Valenzuela | bvalenzuela@scng.com | San Bernardino Sun
PUBLISHED: July 10, 2018 at 10:08 am | UPDATED: July 11, 2018 at 2:53 am

Crystal Reyna Gonzalez (Courtesy)

A Fontana woman was arrested after she allegedly left her two young children — ages 1 year and 9 months — in a car in nearly 100-degree weather while she shopped at an Ontario Walmart for about half an hour, Ontario police said.


Crystal Reyna Gonzales, 34, was arrested Sunday evening on suspicion of cruelty to a child after several people, including a security officer, noticed the children inside the white SUV and called police, officials said. She has since posted $100,000 bail and was released.


Gonzales told Ontario police she is the mother of both children. Police said it’s unknown at this time if she is their biological mother.


“The AC was not on, the windows were slightly cracked, but the car was off and the doors were locked,” Ontario police Detective Melissa Ramirez said. “We estimate she was in the store for at least half an hour. Investigators are reviewing video surveillance for a more accurate time.”


Around 7:45 p.m., Curtis Owens and his family were leaving Walmart when he noticed the large white SUV was not parked correctly.


“That’s the first thing I notice,” Owens of Ontario said. “Then I hear music. The music is playing but I didn’t see anyone inside. Then my daughter says, ‘I think someone is in there.’ I look in the backseat and that’s when I see the carseat and I see the toddler.”


Shocked and panicked at seeing the child inside the hot car, Owens tried to open the doors of the vehicle but they were locked, he said. He then ran back into the store and alerted employees a child was locked inside a hot vehicle.


“At that point, I think people saw me being frantic and started gathering around the vehicle,” Owens said.


He ran back outside and began a Facebook Live recording. In the video, Owens recorded for more than 11 minutes before Gonzales appeared and was questioned by officers.


“A security guard who works at the store called 911 when the guard saw numerous people gathered around a white GMC,” Ramirez said. “When she realized there were two young children — age 1 year and 9 months — in distress due to the high temperatures she called the police.”

Sign up for our breaking news email newsletter: When major local news happens, you will be the first to know. Subscribe here.

According to the National Weather Service, the temperature in Ontario was about 95 degrees at the time the call came in but Owens said it felt a lot hotter.


“I honestly wanted to pull those babies out and hold them until someone arrived,” he said, but waited for police and rescue personnel.


Related Articles

  * Riverside County officials try to capture, treat wild burro shot with an arrow
  * Man gets 3 years in prison for making illegal drugs after his lab ignited a house fire in Wildomar
  * Ontario man accused of sexually assaulting child
  * Fewer searchers now looking for hiker in Joshua Tree National Park
  * Teen shooting victim abandoned in Yucaipa was involved in burglary, sheriff says

“Both children were medically evaluated at the scene but ended up not needing to be transported to a hospital,” Ramirez said. The children were handed over to Child Protective Services.


In the video, people can be heard thanking Owens for being vigilant and saving the children’s lives, but for the father and husband, he feels he did what anyone else would do.


“I don’t think it’s about being a father or mother, it’s about those children and I would like to think that anyone else in the same situation would be alert and aware and do the same thing,” he said.


The case is still under investigation.


Anyone with information about the investigation can contact Ontario Detective Steve Munoz at 909-408-1462.

Local News


Poet, photographer tell laborers’ stories with images, phrases


Share this:

  * Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)
  * Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)
  * Click to print (Opens in new window)

* This black-and-white photo of a laborer, superimposed over a color image of a grove, illustrates creatively the often invisible force behind the Inland Empire’s citrus industry. The poster-sized art with the poetic line is displayed along a trail in California Citrus State Historical Park in Riverside. (Photo courtesy of Thomas McGovern and Juan Delgado)
By David Downey | ddowney@scng.com | The Press-Enterprise

PUBLISHED: July 15, 2018 at 6:05 am | UPDATED: July 15, 2018 at 6:05 am

  * Another portrait of an unidentified laborer working in the groves at California Citrus State Historic Park during the orange harvest in early 2017 is displayed along a park trail and paired with a line of poetry. (Photo courtesy of Thomas McGovern and Juan Delgado)


  * Photographer Thomas McGovern, left, and Poet Juan Delgado are pictured in San Bernardino in this 2013 file photo.

  * Sound
    The gallery will resume inseconds

  * A Juan Delgado poem offers perspective for a the mostly hidden face of a laborer working in the groves at California Citrus State Historic Park in early 2017, and captured in a Thomas McGovern photo featured in a park exhibit. (Photo courtesy of Thomas McGovern and Juan Delgado)


* Show Caption

of

Expand


Poetry and photography have been combined to tell the story of the Inland Empire citrus laborer.


At 10 stations spaced along a trail meandering through the scenic groves of California Citrus State Historic Park in Riverside, black-and-white poster-sized photographs capture the faces of hard-working pickers while poetic lines of text place them in context.


The displays debuted in May 2017. They are a product of a partnership between the park and UC Riverside that seeks to tell a more complete history of the region’s storied citrus industry.


The photos were taken by photographer Thomas McGovern, a professor of art at Cal State San Bernardino, and they were superimposed over large color photos of citrus trees.

Sign up for The Localist, our daily email newsletter with handpicked stories relevant to where you live. Subscribe here.

The images are paired with catchy phrases coined by poet Juan Delgado, a retired Cal State San Bernardino professor of English.


The two artists also collaborated on “Vital Signs,” an earlier award-winning book about San Bernardino.


One line in the citrus exhibit states: “He is beside you behind a curtain of quivering leaves.” It is positioned beneath the portrait of an unidentified man with a proud, weathered face who looks to be in his upper 50s.


The inspiration for that illustration and others came from a visit Delgado and McGovern paid during the orange harvest of early 2017. Although the trees are inside a state park, they are harvested commercially by local growers.


“The men were moving in and out of the trees and you could lose a person very quickly,” Delgado said. “They were very nimble and very quick. You could hear the working and the rustling. But you couldn’t see them.”


As he frequently lost sight of the pickers behind one tree or another, it occurred to Delgado that society often misses the behind-the-scenes contributions laborers have made to the wildly successful and iconic industry that has shaped much of Inland Empire history.


“It was a metaphor for the invisibility of their labor,” he said.


Related Articles

  * Which are the best, worst states to retire to? (Hint: Neither is California, by these rankings)
  * Riverside County officials try to capture, treat wild burro shot with an arrow
  * ‘Brady Bunch’ home in Studio City for sale
  * Man gets 3 years in prison for making illegal drugs after his lab ignited a house fire in Wildomar
  * Fewer searchers now looking for hiker in Joshua Tree National Park

Delgado and McGovern hope the illustrations will begin to move the public’s appreciation for the laborer out from behind the curtain of quivering leaves.


“The idea was to show this picturesque beautiful grove and, in that, to demonstrate what it takes to get these oranges from the grove to the grocery store,” McGovern said.

(Photo by Cindy Yamanaka, The Press-Enterprise/SCNG) By David Downey | ddowney@scng.com | The Press-Enterprise PUBLISHED: July 15, 2018 at 6:00 am | UPDATED: July 15, 2018 at 6:02 am Visitors strolling through the aromatic groves at California Citrus State Historic Park in Riverside can’t help but be awestruck by the rows of verdant fruit trees that hearken back to a rich chapter in Inland Empire history. But something is missing from the picture. “When you look out here, you see trees, but the trees are empty of people’s voices,” said park interpreter Steve Moreno-Terrill, who was leading a tour of the 250-acre state park. What’s missing are the faces, names and stories of thousands of workers who labored in the once-sprawling groves and packing houses, said park officials and researchers. Citizens from diverse ethnic backgrounds and immigrants from all over the world — Chinese, Italians, Japanese, Koreans, Mexicans and others — all played a part. “With citrus, what’s really important is that this entire region was built on the backs of the labor of so many different groups of people,” said Cathy Gudis, director of UC Riverside’s Public History program. (Photo by Cindy Yamanaka, The Press-Enterprise/SCNG) Show Caption of Expand With that in mind, Gudis and other researchers set out to fill gaps in local history through the Relevancy and History Project, a partnership between UCR and California’s park system. Launched in 2016, it’s an experimental program that may be replicated at other state parks with deep ties to history, Gudis said. The goal is “to bring to life stories that have not necessarily been publicly shared because traditional archives, museums and historical societies didn’t always collect, save or present the stories of working people — that face of our population who may not have been part of the managerial elite,” she said. Since World War II, Latinas such as Lupe Vasquez, Margaret Rodriguez, and Elsie Frogge of Riverside, pictured here in this photo from the 1940s, have done much of the work in area packing houses.
(Photo courtesy of Collection of Riverside Metropolitan Museum) In March, the project gave birth to an exhibit in the visitor-center lobby that bears the name, “Finding Ourselves in the Groves: Stories and Storytellers of Citrus in Inland Southern California.” The display highlights the laborers in the decades following Eliza Tibbets‘ famous planting of the parent navel orange tree in Riverside in 1873. The display also showcases the African-American settlers who shaped the industry as grove owners, arborists and investors. And it mentions the contributions of Native American youth from the Sherman Institute boarding school who worked in the fields. By shining a spotlight on the waves of people brought to the Inland Empire to pick and pack, the exhibit doubles as a snapshot of changing U.S. immigration policy. An especially formative policy was the Bracero Program launched in 1942, at the height of World War II, which replenished the nation’s dwindling labor supply and opened the door for Mexican citizens to enter the U.S. as guest workers. But the exhibit isn’t just about groups. It’s also about individuals. Japanese picking crews for Arlington Heights Fruit Co. harvest fruit in Riverside citrus groves during the 1910s. (Photo courtesy of Collection of Riverside Public Library) One such individual is 72-year-old Riverside native Manuel Venegas, who spent much of his childhood working the groves. At age 5, he picked low-hanging fruit while his father and oldest brother harvested oranges or lemons higher up in the trees. “They called us ratas — rats — because we would pick the bottom,” Venegas said in an interview. He’d work from 7 a.m. until noon. “Of course, some of that was fooling around — chasing rabbits and things like that,” he said. As Venegas got older, he shifted his focus from rabbits to efficiency. “My brothers and I got so good we would quit when we got 100 boxes — each — and we would get 100 boxes by noon,” he said, adding that a box contained about 60 pounds of fruit. Venegas still has the clippers he used to cut stems and the canvas bag that held the oranges he picked. A 2017 portrait of Venegas graces a wall inside the visitor center entrance. His wife, Yolanda, said their grandson was overwhelmed when he first saw it. “He just thought, ‘My grandpa’s famous.’” The exhibit also features a much older photo of his late father, Joe Venegas, and older brother, Joe Venegas Jr., provided by his family. The picture is an example of the historical treasures the Relevancy and History Project mined from local family collections over the past two years. On about three dozen occasions, researchers gathered people at festivals, cultural events, libraries, museums and historical society meetings in San Bernardino, Riverside, Redlands, Banning and Loma Linda to explain the project and solicit their help. Armed with a state grant that will keep the project going through March 2019, team members said they intend to continue building upon the trove of photographs, artifacts and oral histories. Park interpreter Megan Suster said the team emphasizes that people’s personal recollections are important parts of local history. “That’s what we’re trying to tell people: Your stories matter,” Suster said. As that point is driven home, Moreno-Terrill said, people’s faces light up as they enthusiastically recount their picking and packing experiences. And team members often are surprised by what they found. “Almost everyone we met with — no matter their race — said they had to pick when they were kids,” Gudis said. “It quickly became obvious that citrus runs deep here.” Related links * RIVERSIDE: Citrus label collection preserves history * CASA BLANCA: Legacy of citrus and community activism * Redlands’ Mexican-American history * RIVERSIDE: City looks to re-imagine historic packing house area * CASSIE MACDUFF: Cheers to a new day at California Citrus State Historic Park It also became obvious that women and children played key roles. And the exhibit points that out. A “Women’s Work” display notes that packing has largely been the responsibility of females going back to the 1890s and primarily of Latinas since World War II. Then there is a “Child’s Play” display that spotlights youngsters’ experiences and adds an element of fun to the exhibit’s serious historical portrait. One of its features is a black-and-white photo from about 1895 of boys playing in the Gage Canal, used to irrigate the groves. “That’s where a lot of people learned how to swim,” Gudis said. Interestingly, she added, it’s also where some learned to surf. Kids surfed the canal by having a horse run alongside the waterway and pull them on a plank of floating plywood. STATE PARK TOURS What: Private tours for groups of up to 50 people exploring the region’s agricultural history Where: California Citrus State Historic Park, 9400 Dufferin Ave., Riverside When: Available through September from 10 to 11:30 a.m. and 1:30 to 3 p.m. on Mondays, and from 9 to 10:30 a.m. on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays How: Private tours must be arranged in advance by contacting Megan Suster at megan.suster@parks.ca.gov or by calling 951-780-6222 Other tours: Regular tours are given at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m. on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. No reservations are required. Cost: There is a parking fee of $5 per vehicle. There is no charge for admission. Get the latest news delivered daily!
